hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
qwen3-235b-a22b-think-parser-fireworks_t:
"Then Puali‘i grabbed his knife and went straight to where Nāmakaokapāo‘o was boiling his four sweet potato vines atop the fire. All the children were utterly terrified, fleeing and standing far away out of fear of Puali‘i. Puali‘i declared to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: 'Hey! Here is my knife in my hand – today it will sever your head, chop off your head, then cook it with the sweet potato, and I myself shall eat it first, and only then will it be Kapu noa.' Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no heed to Puali‘i's words and spoke again, this time a second time. Puali‘i prepared to slice off Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head with the knife when Nāmakaokapāo‘o recited his death chant toward Puali‘i. He chanted thus:
The eyes of my pāoʻo fish here melt away.
Be silenced, fall prostrate face-down.
May you be devoured, may you be left behind.
May you be left behind, Kukui‘aimakaokalani.
That one is Kukui‘aimakaokalani,
This one is my lover.
Nāmakaokaiʻa, the great chief of Hawaiʻi,
May you flee, may you flee entirely.
It is the warrior with the spear,
The spear with the pahu drum.
Death to Nāmakaokapāo‘o."
qwen3-235b-a22b-think-parser-fireworks_c:
**Paragraph 7:**  
• **Name Etymologies & Divine Symbolism:**  
– *Pua-li‘i* (child of the ruler): His aggressive assertion of dominance with a **knife** (*koʻilipi*, an iron blade introduced post-European contact) reflects a hybridization of traditional chiefly authority (*aliʻi*) and foreign violence. His threat to "eat" Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s head mirrors *ʻAi Kapu* rituals where *ulua* substituted human sacrifice, but inverted—he weaponizes sacred cannibalism to uphold oppressive power.  
– *Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo* (the eyes of the *pāoʻo* fish): His defiance amidst boiling *ʻōʻo* (sweet potato vines) ties him to *Kāne*, the god of freshwater and agriculture. The four vines likely symbolize the four *mauʻu* (districts) of Oʻahu, or the four winds of cosmological significance, subverting Pualiʻi’s violence into sacred agricultural renewal.  

• **Numerological Allegory & Subsistence Significance:**  
– The four (*ʻehā*) *ʻau ʻuala* (sweet potato vines) contrast with prior paragraphs’ "two patches" and "40 mounds," reinforcing cyclical time and the *kālana* (reward) of patience. Roasting vines, not tubers, symbolically preserves *ʻuala*’s life-force (*mana*) for replanting, opposing Pualiʻi’s destructive consumption.  
– The children fleeing to a *kahi lōʻihi* (far place) mirrors the mythic departure of *kupua* (demigods) from human settlements during spiritual trials, emphasizing Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s status as a supernatural figure transcending mortal fear.  

• **Incantation Analysis & Subversion of Kapu:**  
– Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s *pule make* (death chant) layers multiple strata of meaning:  
– *Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāoʻo* ("The eyes of my pāoʻo fish just melt away"): Replaces Pualiʻi’s head-eating threat with a *pāoʻo* (smooth fish) metaphor, symbolizing fluid, indirect power (e.g., water’s persistence vs. iron’s rigidity).  
– *Kukuiʻaimakaokalani* (Beloved light [of heaven]): A veiled invocation of *Kāne*, the god of light (kukui) and heaven (kalani), seeking divine reconciliation. The name *Kukuiʻaimakaokalani* contains double *ma-* (“to serve” or “to die”; Elbert & Pukui, *Hawaiian Dictionary*), suggesting Pualiʻi’s death as an offering to reassert cosmic balance.  
– *Nāmakaokaiʻa* (The eyes of seawater): Shifts from *pāoʻo* (terrestrial fish) to *kaiʻa* (ocean fish), evoking *Namaka*, the water goddess, to unleash chaos against Pualiʻi. This duality (freshwater/saltwater) merges agricultural and marine domains under his control.  
– Chant’s climax: The *ihe* (spear) and *pahu* (drum) combo evokes *Pākanu* (war gods of Kāne and Kanaloa), but here they become a mortal koʻē (failure). By narrating his own death (*Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāoʻo*), the kūpua enacts auto-sacrifice to transmute Pualiʻi’s wrath into collective liberation, subverting *ʻAi Kapu*’s rigidity.  

• **Technological & Cultural Syncretism:**  
– *Koʻilipi* (knife) bridges pre-contact Stone Age tools and post-contact colonial weapons, reflecting the story’s *pilina ʻano* (hybrid temporality). Pualiʻi’s reliance on iron signifies dependency on foreign systems, whereas Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s fire-roasted *ʻuala* (native crop) asserts Indigenous sustenance practices.  
– *Kapu noa* (“only then will it be Kapu noa”): Pualiʻi’s jab at Kapu lifting mocks the chant’s purpose: Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s curse instead *consecrates* Pualiʻi’s death as a Kapu-breaking sacrifice that paves the way for *ʻAi Noa* (freedom from Kapu).
raw_response:
<translation>
"Then Puali‘i grabbed his knife and went straight to where Nāmakaokapāo‘o was boiling his four sweet potato vines atop the fire. All the children were utterly terrified, fleeing and standing far away out of fear of Puali‘i. Puali‘i declared to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: 'Hey! Here is my knife in my hand – today it will sever your head, chop off your head, then cook it with the sweet potato, and I myself shall eat it first, and only then will it be Kapu noa.' Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no heed to Puali‘i's words and spoke again, this time a second time. Puali‘i prepared to slice off Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head with the knife when Nāmakaokapāo‘o recited his death chant toward Puali‘i. He chanted thus:
The eyes of my pāoʻo fish here melt away.
Be silenced, fall prostrate face-down.
May you be devoured, may you be left behind.
May you be left behind, Kukui‘aimakaokalani.
That one is Kukui‘aimakaokalani,
This one is my lover.
Nāmakaokaiʻa, the great chief of Hawaiʻi,
May you flee, may you flee entirely.
It is the warrior with the spear,
The spear with the pahu drum.
Death to Nāmakaokapāo‘o."
</translation>

---

<commentary>
**Paragraph 7:**  
• **Name Etymologies & Divine Symbolism:**  
– *Pua-li‘i* (child of the ruler): His aggressive assertion of dominance with a **knife** (*koʻilipi*, an iron blade introduced post-European contact) reflects a hybridization of traditional chiefly authority (*aliʻi*) and foreign violence. His threat to "eat" Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s head mirrors *ʻAi Kapu* rituals where *ulua* substituted human sacrifice, but inverted—he weaponizes sacred cannibalism to uphold oppressive power.  
– *Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo* (the eyes of the *pāoʻo* fish): His defiance amidst boiling *ʻōʻo* (sweet potato vines) ties him to *Kāne*, the god of freshwater and agriculture. The four vines likely symbolize the four *mauʻu* (districts) of Oʻahu, or the four winds of cosmological significance, subverting Pualiʻi’s violence into sacred agricultural renewal.  

• **Numerological Allegory & Subsistence Significance:**  
– The four (*ʻehā*) *ʻau ʻuala* (sweet potato vines) contrast with prior paragraphs’ "two patches" and "40 mounds," reinforcing cyclical time and the *kālana* (reward) of patience. Roasting vines, not tubers, symbolically preserves *ʻuala*’s life-force (*mana*) for replanting, opposing Pualiʻi’s destructive consumption.  
– The children fleeing to a *kahi lōʻihi* (far place) mirrors the mythic departure of *kupua* (demigods) from human settlements during spiritual trials, emphasizing Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s status as a supernatural figure transcending mortal fear.  

• **Incantation Analysis & Subversion of Kapu:**  
– Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s *pule make* (death chant) layers multiple strata of meaning:  
– *Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāoʻo* ("The eyes of my pāoʻo fish just melt away"): Replaces Pualiʻi’s head-eating threat with a *pāoʻo* (smooth fish) metaphor, symbolizing fluid, indirect power (e.g., water’s persistence vs. iron’s rigidity).  
– *Kukuiʻaimakaokalani* (Beloved light [of heaven]): A veiled invocation of *Kāne*, the god of light (kukui) and heaven (kalani), seeking divine reconciliation. The name *Kukuiʻaimakaokalani* contains double *ma-* (“to serve” or “to die”; Elbert & Pukui, *Hawaiian Dictionary*), suggesting Pualiʻi’s death as an offering to reassert cosmic balance.  
– *Nāmakaokaiʻa* (The eyes of seawater): Shifts from *pāoʻo* (terrestrial fish) to *kaiʻa* (ocean fish), evoking *Namaka*, the water goddess, to unleash chaos against Pualiʻi. This duality (freshwater/saltwater) merges agricultural and marine domains under his control.  
– Chant’s climax: The *ihe* (spear) and *pahu* (drum) combo evokes *Pākanu* (war gods of Kāne and Kanaloa), but here they become a mortal koʻē (failure). By narrating his own death (*Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāoʻo*), the kūpua enacts auto-sacrifice to transmute Pualiʻi’s wrath into collective liberation, subverting *ʻAi Kapu*’s rigidity.  

• **Technological & Cultural Syncretism:**  
– *Koʻilipi* (knife) bridges pre-contact Stone Age tools and post-contact colonial weapons, reflecting the story’s *pilina ʻano* (hybrid temporality). Pualiʻi’s reliance on iron signifies dependency on foreign systems, whereas Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s fire-roasted *ʻuala* (native crop) asserts Indigenous sustenance practices.  
– *Kapu noa* (“only then will it be Kapu noa”): Pualiʻi’s jab at Kapu lifting mocks the chant’s purpose: Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s curse instead *consecrates* Pualiʻi’s death as a Kapu-breaking sacrifice that paves the way for *ʻAi Noa* (freedom from Kapu).  
</commentary>
reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
